metadata.title: Italian Society of Interventional Cardiology (GISE) position paper for Cath lab‐specific preparedness recommendations for healthcare providers in case of suspected, probable or confirmed cases of COVID‐19

body_text.text: If the hospital has multiple cath‐labs/operating rooms, it is suggested to identify dedicated lab for the treatment of suspected or confirmed COVID‐19 patients, if needed.
body_text.section: Daily checklist in cath lab ::: GENERAL MANAGEMENT OF CATH LAB

body_text.text: Only clinical staff who have been trained and is therefore considered to be competent in the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) should be allowed to access the cath lab in case of suspected or confirmed COVID‐19 patients.
body_text.section: Daily checklist in cath lab ::: GENERAL MANAGEMENT OF CATH LAB

body_text.text: Due to the spread of infection worldwide and the risk of supply shortages of PPE, it is recommended to have a dedicated registry of all the available PPE in cath lab.
body_text.section: Daily checklist in cath lab ::: GENERAL MANAGEMENT OF CATH LAB

body_text.text: It is suggested to do a daily check to verify the presence of an adequate number of PPE including:Surgical maskRespirator N95 or FFP2 standard and FFP3, or equivalent.Long‐sleeved water‐resistant gownSterile standard gownGlovesHair coversEye protection (goggles or face shield, better if disposable)Apron (for aerosol‐generating procedures such as intubation)Shoe covers due to the risk of splash from organic material or chemicals.
body_text.section: Daily checklist in cath lab ::: GENERAL MANAGEMENT OF CATH LAB

body_text.text: It is advised to alert the anesthesiologist beforehand to consider the opportunity of elective intubation before patient arrival in cath lab.
body_text.section: Daily checklist of crash cart ::: GENERAL MANAGEMENT OF CATH LAB

body_text.text: In any case, the crash cart must contain:Heat and moisture exchanger (HME) filters to be placed on any interface (mask, circuit, endotracheal tube, supraglottic devices, introducer/exchange pipes)LaryngoscopeMasksCircuitsEndotracheal tubesSupraglottic devicesIntroducer/exchange pipesAspirator (closed system)Anti‐fogging systemAny potential useful drugs already prepared and double checkedClamp, if necessary to disconnect the patient from the ventilator.
body_text.section: Daily checklist of crash cart ::: GENERAL MANAGEMENT OF CATH LAB

body_text.text: All HCWs involved in the procedure must wear proper PPE before patient's arrival in cath lab in a safe noncontaminated environment. The sequence is:Remove any personal itemsPut on the lead apronPut on a first disposable gownGather the necessary PPE and check for their integrityPerform hand hygiene with alcohol hand gel/rubPut on the proper disposable respirator N95 or FFP2 standard (FFP3 available for anesthesiologist and nurse helping on airways maneuvers)Put on hair coverPut on shoe coversPut on googles and/or face shield avoiding any interference with the respiratorPerform hand hygienePut on the first pair of glovesPut on a gown (sterile or not according to your role in cath lab) not using the inside tiePut on a second pair of gloves (over cuff), sterile if needed.
body_text.section: Donning of PPE before entering Cath lab ::: PROCEDURES FOR WEARING (“DONNING”) AND SAFE REMOVAL (“DOFFING”) OF PPE

body_text.text: A safe doffing area should be identified in each cath lab, in particular if no anteroom or exists. If no anteroom is available, doffing of PPE could be done inside the lab, at the end of procedure and when the patient has been transferred away.
body_text.section:
Doffing of PPE
 ::: PROCEDURES FOR WEARING (“DONNING”) AND SAFE REMOVAL (“DOFFING”) OF PPE

body_text.text: Only facial respirator must be removed outside the contaminated area.Avoid any contact with your face, hair and eyes before of completing the entire doffing process.Place any disposable PPE in the clinical waste bin.Do not fill the clinical waste bin more than ¾ in order to be able to close it safely without squeezing contaminated materials to avoid aerosolization.Reprocess the not‐disposable PPE.Follow the sequence.
body_text.section:
Doffing of PPE
 ::: PROCEDURES FOR WEARING (“DONNING”) AND SAFE REMOVAL (“DOFFING”) OF PPE

body_text.text: Inside the operating room:Wait until patient is out of the room; close the door.Perform hand hygiene over the gloves.Peel off gown and gloves together and roll inside, slowly and carefully, avoiding aerosolization.If gloves are removed separately, touch only the external part (use glove‐in‐glove or beak technique).Perform hand hygiene (over the internal gloves).Remove face shield and/or googles avoiding contact with face and eyes and dispose them safely or put in a separate container for reprocessing.Perform hand hygiene (over the internal gloves).Remove hair cover and dispone it safely.Remove shoe covers and dispone them safely.Perform hand hygiene (over the internal gloves).Remove internal gloves and dispose them safely.Perform hand hygiene.Step out of the operating room and immediately close the door.
body_text.section:
Doffing of PPE
 ::: PROCEDURES FOR WEARING (“DONNING”) AND SAFE REMOVAL (“DOFFING”) OF PPE

body_text.text: Outside the operating room:Put on another pair of gloves.Remove facial respirator without touching the front side of the respirator.Remove the disposable gown and the gloves.Remove lead apron.Perform hand hygiene with soap and water and alcohol gel/rub.
body_text.section:
Doffing of PPE
 ::: PROCEDURES FOR WEARING (“DONNING”) AND SAFE REMOVAL (“DOFFING”) OF PPE

body_text.text: Notify the area receiving the patient of any necessary precautions as early as possible before the patient's arrival.Ensure maximal coordination to avoid steadying in waiting areas.Get all other patients in cath lab away from the path the COVID patient will have to take.Identify the staff that will be in contact with the patient avoiding unnecessary exposure of other members in order to reduce the risk of contamination and wasting of PPE.Assign roles to each staff member.Briefing with the (few) member of the dedicated staff, identify a buddy who is designated to read the instructions and supervised the correct sequence of donning and doffing.Pre‐warning of the anesthesiologist to evaluate the opportunity of elective intubation, recommended before patient's arrival in the lab; otherwise, the anesthesiologist stays outside the room with proper PPE.All useful material for interventional cardiology must be stored inside the lab (for instance a full‐size series of catheters, balloon‐catheters and stents), avoiding entry and exit of the staff members during procedure.Any useful drugs have to be prepared in advance.Supervised donning PPE for all the member of the staff (it is suggested to have at least one physician and one nurse sterile and one nurse and one technician nonsterile).Only when all is prepared, accept the patient in cath lab.If in spontaneous breathing, the patient must wear a surgical mask before entry the lab.
body_text.section: WHAT TO DO BEFORE THE ARRIVAL IN CATH‐LAB OF A SUSPECTED OR CONFIRMED COVID‐19 PATIENT

body_text.text: Keep the door closed for the whole duration of procedure.PPE‐protected (but nonsterile) member staff put the patient on the operating table.Avoid entry and exit from the room of the staff for bringing material (everything necessary should be planned in advance and stored inside).Nonsterile staff members moving into the operating room during the procedure should minimize any contact with the surfaces. Before any contact (for example before opening a tray), he should change the external gloves (or put on another pair of cleaned gloves).Keep the procedure as simple as possible (only culprit lesion revascularization).
body_text.section: PERIPROCEDURAL MANAGEMENT OF SUSPECTED OR CONFIRMED COVID‐19 PATIENTS IN CATH‐LAB

body_text.text: Keep the door closed.Supervised doffing as previously described; if no anteroom is available, doffing of PPE could be done inside the room, at the end of procedure and when the patient has been transferred away. Only facial respirator must be removed outside the contaminated area.Dispose of all waste according to protocols (do not squeeze contaminated material into the container).Treat used tissues in accordance with standard procedures.Get out of the operating room and keep the door closed for at least an hour prior to performing a terminal clean (in particular for a neutral pressure room).Reuseable equipments have to be decontaminated according to the manufacturer's instructions (i.e., lead apron).Notification of any new confirmed case.A record of all staff providing care for suspected or confirmed 2019‐nCoV cases must be maintained.If at any point a member of the staff feels as he/she has been exposed to the pathogen, follow facility protocols.Staff who have been provided care to confirmed 2019‐nCoV cases, should be vigilant for fever and any respiratory symptoms in the 14 days following the last exposure to a confirmed case, and follow internal protocols.
body_text.section: POST‐PROCEDURAL REQUIREMENTS WHEN A SUSPECTED OR CONFIRMED COVID‐19 PATIENT LEAVES THE CATH‐LAB

body_text.text: The authors declare no potential conflict of interest.
